<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Local_developments_and_divergences_from_Chinese">Local developments and divergences from Chinese</span></h2>
<p>Since Kanji are essentially Chinese <i><a href="/wiki/Hanzi" title="Hanzi" class="mw-redirect">hanzi</a></i> used to write Japanese, the majority of kanji used in modern Japanese still retain their Chinese meaning (especially with their modern <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese characters</a> counterparts) and retain a degree of similarity in pronunciation with Classical Chinese pronunciation imported to Japan from 5th to 9th century. Nevertheless, after centuries of development, there is a notable number of kanji used in modern Japanese which have different meaning from Chinese characters used in modern Chinese. Such differences are the result of (i) the use of characters created in Japan, (ii) characters that have been given different meanings in Japanese, and (iii) post-<a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> simplifications of the kanji. Likewise, the process of <a href="/wiki/Simplified_characters" title="Simplified characters" class="mw-redirect">character simplification</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a> since the 1950s has the result that Japanese speakers who have not studied Chinese may not recognize some simplified characters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kokuji">Kokuji</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Also&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Also (page does not exist)">Template:Also</a>
<i>Kokuji</i> (<span lang="ja">国字</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, "national characters") are characters particular to Japan, generally devised in Japan. The term <i>wasei kanji</i> (<span lang="ja">和製漢字</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, "kanji made in Japan") is also used to refer to <i>kokuji</i>. These are primarily formed in the usual way of Chinese characters, namely by combining existing components, though using a combination that is not used in China. The corresponding phenomenon in Korea is called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Gukja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gukja (page does not exist)">gukja</a></i> (國字), which is the cognate term; there are however far fewer Korean-coined characters than Japanese-coined ones. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_family_of_scripts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese family of scripts (page does not exist)">Other languages</a> using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_family_of_scripts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese family of scripts (page does not exist)">Chinese family of scripts</a> sometimes have far more extensive systems of native characters, most significantly Vietnamese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ch%E1%BB%AF_n%C3%B4m&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chữ nôm (page does not exist)">chữ nôm</a>, which comprises over 20,000 characters used throughout traditional Vietnamese writing, and <a href="/wiki/Zhuang_languages" title="Zhuang languages">Zhuang</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sawndip&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sawndip (page does not exist)">sawndip</a>, which comprises over 10,000 characters, which are still in use.
</p><p>Since kokuji are generally devised for existing native words, these usually only have native <a href="/wiki/Kun_reading#Kun.27yomi_.28Japanese_reading.29" title="Kun reading" class="mw-redirect"><i>kun</i> readings</a>. However, they occasionally have a Chinese <a href="/wiki/On_reading#On.27yomi_.28Sino-Japanese_reading.29" title="On reading" class="mw-redirect"><i>on</i> reading</a>, derived from a phonetic, as in <span lang="ja">働</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, <i>dō,</i> from <span lang="ja">動</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, and in rare cases only have an <i>on</i> reading, as in <span lang="ja">腺</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, <i>sen,</i> from <span lang="ja">泉</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, which was derived for use in technical compounds (<span lang="ja">腺</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> means "gland", hence used in medical terminology).
</p><p>The majority of kokuji are <a href="/wiki/Chinese_character_classification#Ideogrammatic_compounds" title="Chinese character classification">ideogrammatic compounds</a> (<span lang="ja">会意字</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>), meaning that they are composed of two (or more) characters, with the meaning associated with the combination. For example, 働 is composed of 亻 (person radical) plus 動 (action), hence "action of a person, work". This is in contrast to kanji generally, which are overwhelmingly phono-semantic compounds. This difference is because kokuji were coined to express Japanese words, so borrowing existing (Chinese) readings could not express these – combining existing characters to logically express the meaning was the simplest way to achieve this. Other illustrative examples (below) include <span lang="ja">榊</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sakaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sakaki (page does not exist)">sakaki</a></i> tree, formed as 木 "tree" and <span lang="ja">神</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> "god", literally "divine tree", and <span lang="ja">辻</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> <i>tsuji</i> "crossroads, street" formed as <span lang="ja">辶</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> (⻌) "road" and <span lang="ja">十</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> "cross", hence "cross-road".
</p><p>In terms of meanings, these are especially for natural phenomena (esp. species) that were not present in ancient China, including a very large number of fish, such as 鰯 (sardine). In other cases they refer to specifically Japanese abstract concepts, everyday words (like 辻), or later technical coinages (such as 腺).
</p><p>There are hundreds of <i>kokuji</i> in existence.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>  Many are rarely used, but a number have become commonly used components of the written Japanese language. These include the following:
</p><p>Jōyō kanji has about 9 kokuji; there is some dispute over classification, but generally includes these:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <span lang="ja">働</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> どう <i>dō</i>, はたら(く) <i>hatara(ku)</i> "work", the most commonly used kokuji, used in the fundamental verb 働く <i>hatara(ku)</i> "work", included in elementary texts and on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Language_Proficiency_Test&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Language Proficiency Test (page does not exist)">Japanese Language Proficiency Test</a> N5, for example.
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">込</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> こ(む) <i>ko(mu)</i>,　used in the fundamental verb 込む（こむ） <i>komu</i> "to be crowded"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">匂</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> にお(う) <i>nio(u)</i>, used in common verb 匂う（におう） <i>niou</i> "to smell, to be fragrant"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">畑</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> はたけ <i>hatake</i> "field of crops"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">腺</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> せん <i>sen</i>, "gland"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">峠</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> とうげ <i>tōge</i> "mountain pass"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">枠</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> わく <i>waku</i>, "frame"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">塀</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> へい <i>hei</i>, "wall"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">搾</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> しぼ（る） <i>shibo(ru)</i>, "to squeeze" (disputed; see below)
</li>
</ul>
<p>Jinmeiyō kanji:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <span lang="ja">榊</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> さかき <i>sakaki</i> "tree, genus <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sakaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sakaki (page does not exist)">Cleyera</a></i>"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">辻</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> つじ <i>tsuji</i> "crossroads, street"
</li>
<li> <span lang="ja">匁</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> もんめ <i>monme</i> (unit of weight)
</li>
</ul>
<p>Hyōgaiji:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <span lang="ja">躾</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>　しつ（け） <i>shitsu(ke)</i> "training, rearing (an animal, a child)"
</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these characters (for example, 腺, "gland"<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>) have been introduced to China. In some cases the Chinese reading is the inferred Chinese reading, interpreting the character as a phono-semantic compound (as in how <i>on</i> readings are sometimes assigned to these characters in Chinese), while in other cases (such as 働), the Japanese <i>on</i> reading is borrowed (in general this differs from the modern Chinese pronunciation of this phonetic). Similar coinages occurred to a more limited extent in Korea and Vietnam.
</p><p>Historically, some kokuji date back to very early Japanese writing, being found in the <i><a href="/wiki/Man%27y%C5%8Dsh%C5%AB" title="Man'yōshū">Man'yōshū</a>,</i> for example – 鰯 <i>iwashi</i> "sardine" dates to the <a href="/wiki/Nara_period" title="Nara period">Nara period</a> (8th century) – while they have continued to be created as late as the late 19th century, when a number of characters were coined in the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_era" title="Meiji era" class="mw-redirect">Meiji era</a> for new scientific concepts. For example, some characters were produced as regular compounds for some (but not all) SI units, such as 粁 (米 "meter" + 千 "thousand, kilo-") for kilometer – see <a href="/wiki/International_System_of_Units#Representation_of_SI_units_in_Chinese_and_Japanese" title="International System of Units">Chinese characters for SI units</a> for details.
</p><p>In Japan the kokuji category is strictly defined as characters whose <i>earliest</i> appearance is in Japan. If a character appears earlier in the Chinese literature, it is not considered a kokuji even if the character was independently coined in Japan and unrelated to the Chinese character (meaning "not borrowed from Chinese"). In other words, kokuji are not simply characters that were made in Japan, but characters that were <i>first</i> made in Japan. An illustrative example is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>. This spelling was created in Edo period Japan from the <a href="/wiki/Ateji" title="Ateji">ateji</a> (phonetic kanji spelling) 安康 for the existing word <i>ankō</i> by adding the 魚 radical to each character – the characters were "made in Japan". However, 鮟 is not considered kokuji, as it is found in ancient Chinese texts as a corruption of 鰋 (魚匽). 鱇 is considered kokuji, as it has not been found in any earlier Chinese text. Casual listings may be more inclusive, including characters such as 鮟.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Another example is 搾, which is sometimes not considered kokuji due to its earlier presence as a corruption of Chinese 榨.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kokkun">Kokkun</span></h3>
<p>In addition to <i>kokuji</i>, there are kanji that have been given meanings in Japanese different from their original Chinese meanings. These are not considered <i>kokuji</i> but are instead called <i>kok</i><i><a href="/wiki/Kunyomi" title="Kunyomi" class="mw-redirect">kun</a></i> (国訓) and include characters such as:
</p>
<ul>
<li> 藤 <i>fuji</i> (<a href="/wiki/Wisteria" title="Wisteria">wisteria</a>; Ch. <i>téng</i> rattan, cane, vine)
</li>
<li> 沖 <i>oki</i> (<a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/offing" class="extiw" title="wikt:offing">offing</a>, offshore; Ch. <i>chōng</i> rinse, minor river (Cantonese))
</li>
<li> 椿 <i>tsubaki</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/Camellia_japonica" title="Camellia japonica">Camellia japonica</a></i>; Ch. <i>chūn</i> <i><a href="/wiki/Toona" title="Toona">Toona</a></i> spp.)
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types_of_Kanji:_by_category">Types of Kanji: by category</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Han_Dynasty" title="Han Dynasty">Han Dynasty</a> scholar <a href="/wiki/Xu_Shen" title="Xu Shen">Xu Shen</a> in his ancient dictionary <i><a href="/wiki/Shuowen_Jiezi" title="Shuowen Jiezi">Shuowen Jiezi</a></i> classified Chinese characters into six categories (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a> <i>liùshū</i>, Japanese: <i>rikusho</i>). The traditional classification is still taught but is problematic and no longer the focus of modern lexicographic practice, as some categories are not clearly defined, nor are they mutually exclusive: the first four refer to structural composition, while the last two refer to usage.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sh.C5.8Dkei_moji_.28.E8.B1.A1.E5.BD.A2.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Shōkei moji</i> (象形文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Shōkei</i> (Chinese: <i>xiàngxíng</i>) characters are <a href="/wiki/Pictograph" title="Pictograph" class="mw-redirect">pictographic</a> sketches of the object they represent. For example, 目 is an eye, while 木 is a tree. (<i>Shōkei</i> 象形 is also the Japanese word for Egyptian <a href="/wiki/Hieroglyph" title="Hieroglyph">hieroglyphs</a>). The current forms of the characters are very different from the originals, though their representations are more clear in <a href="/wiki/Oracle_bone_script" title="Oracle bone script">oracle bone script</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seal_script" title="Seal script">seal script</a>. These pictographic characters make up only a small fraction of modern characters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shiji_moji_.28.E6.8C.87.E4.BA.8B.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Shiji moji</i> (指事文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Shiji</i> (Chinese: <i>zhǐshì</i>) characters are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ideograph&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ideograph (page does not exist)">ideographs</a>, often called "simple ideographs" or "simple indicatives" to distinguish them and tell the difference from compound ideographs (below). They are usually simple graphically and represent an abstract concept such as 上 "up" or "above" and 下 "down" or "below". These make up a tiny fraction of modern characters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kaii_moji_.28.E4.BC.9A.E6.84.8F.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Kaii moji</i> (会意文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Kaii</i> (Chinese: <i>huìyì</i>) characters are compound ideographs, often called "compound indicatives", "associative compounds", or just "ideographs". These are usually a combination of pictographs that combine semantically to present an overall meaning. An example of this type is 休 (rest) from 人 (person) and 木 (tree).  Another is the <i>kokuji</i> 峠 (mountain pass) made from 山 (mountain), 上 (up) and 下 (down). These make up a tiny fraction of modern characters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Keisei_moji_.28.E5.BD.A2.E5.A3.B0.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Keisei moji</i> (形声文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Keisei</i> (Chinese: <i>xíngshēng</i>) characters are phono-semantic or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radical_(Chinese_character)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radical (Chinese character) (page does not exist)">radical</a>-phonetic compounds, sometimes called "semantic-phonetic", "semasio-phonetic", or "phonetic-ideographic" characters, are by far the largest category, making up about 90% of the characters in the standard lists; however, some of the most frequently used kanji belong to one of the three groups mentioned above, so <i>keisei moji</i> will usually make up less than 90% of the characters in a text. Typically they are made up of two components, one of which (most commonly, but by no means always, the left or top element) suggests the general category of the meaning or semantic context, and the other (most commonly the right or bottom element) approximates the pronunciation. The pronunciation relates to the original Chinese, and may now only be distantly detectable in the modern Japanese <i>on'yomi</i> of the kanji; it generally has no relation at all to <i>kun'yomi</i>. The same is true of the semantic context, which may have changed over the centuries or in the transition from Chinese to Japanese. As a result, it is a common error in folk etymology to fail to recognize a phono-semantic compound, typically instead inventing a compound-indicative explanation.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tench.C5.AB_moji_.28.E8.BB.A2.E6.B3.A8.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Tenchū moji</i> (転注文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Tenchū</i> (Chinese: <i>zhuǎnzhù</i>) characters have variously been called "derivative characters", "derivative <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">cognates</a>", or translated as "mutually explanatory" or "mutually synonymous" characters; this is the most problematic of the six categories, as it is vaguely defined. It may refer to kanji where the meaning or application has become extended. For example, 楽 is used for 'music' and 'comfort, ease', with different pronunciations in Chinese reflected in the two different <i>on'yomi</i>, <i>gaku</i> 'music' and <i>raku</i> 'pleasure'.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kasha_moji_.28.E4.BB.AE.E5.80.9F.E6.96.87.E5.AD.97.29"><i>Kasha moji</i> (仮借文字)</span></h3>
<p><i>Kasha</i> (Chinese: <i>jiǎjiè</i>) are <a href="/wiki/Rebus" title="Rebus">rebuses</a>, sometimes called "phonetic loans". The etymology of the characters follows one of the patterns above, but the present-day meaning is completely unrelated to this. A character was appropriated to represent a similar sounding word. For example, 来 in ancient Chinese was originally a pictograph for "wheat". Its syllable was homophonous with the verb meaning "to come", and the character is used for that verb as a result, without any embellishing "meaning" element attached. The character for wheat 麦, originally meant "to come", being a <i>keisei moji</i> having 'foot' at the bottom for its meaning part and "wheat" at the top for sound. The two characters swapped meaning, so today the more common word has the simpler character. This borrowing of sounds has a very long history.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_symbols">Related symbols</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Iteration_mark" title="Iteration mark">iteration mark</a> (々) is used to indicate that the preceding kanji is to be repeated, functioning similarly to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ditto_mark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ditto mark (page does not exist)">ditto mark</a> in English. It is pronounced as though the kanji were written twice in a row, for example 色々 (<i>iroiro</i> "various") and 時々 (<i>tokidoki</i> "sometimes"). This mark also appears in personal and place names, as in the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_name" title="Japanese name">surname</a> Sasaki (佐々木). This symbol is a simplified version of the kanji 仝 (variant of 同 dō "same").
</p><p>Another abbreviated symbol is <a href="/w/index.php?title=%E3%83%B6&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ヶ (page does not exist)">ヶ</a>, in appearance a small <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">katakana</a> "ke", but actually a simplified version of the kanji 箇, a general counter. It is pronounced "ka" when used to indicate quantity (such as 六ヶ月, <i>rok<b>ka</b>getsu</i> "six months") or "ga" in place names like <a href="/wiki/Kasumigaseki" title="Kasumigaseki">Kasumigaseki</a> (霞ヶ関). .
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Collation">Collation</span></h2>
<p>Kanji, whose thousands of symbols defy ordering by conventions such as those used for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Latin_script&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Latin script (page does not exist)">Latin script</a>, are often <a href="/wiki/Collation" title="Collation">collated</a> using the traditional Chinese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radical-and-stroke_sorting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radical-and-stroke sorting (page does not exist)">radical-and-stroke sorting</a> method. In this system, common components of characters are identified; these are called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radical_(Chinese_character)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radical (Chinese character) (page does not exist)">radicals</a>. Characters are grouped by their primary radical, then ordered by number of pen strokes within radicals. For example, the kanji character <span lang="ja">桜</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, meaning "cherry", is sorted as a ten-stroke character under the four-stroke primary radical <span lang="ja">木</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> meaning "tree". When there is no obvious radical or more than one radical, convention governs which is used for collation.
</p><p>Other kanji sorting methods, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kodansha_Kanji_Learner%27s_Dictionary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kodansha Kanji Learner's Dictionary (page does not exist)">SKIP</a> system, have been devised by various authors.
</p><p>Modern general-purpose <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_dictionaries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese dictionaries (page does not exist)">Japanese dictionaries</a> (as opposed to specifically character dictionaries) generally collate all entries, including words written using kanji, according to their <a href="/wiki/Kana" title="Kana">kana</a> representations (reflecting the way they are pronounced). The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goj%C5%ABon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gojūon (page does not exist)">gojūon</a> ordering of kana is normally used for this purpose.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Kanji_education">Kanji education</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2230_Kanji.svg" title="File:2230 Kanji.svg">File:2230 Kanji.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An image which lists most joyo-kanji, according to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kodansha_Kanji_Learner%27s_Dictionary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kodansha Kanji Learner's Dictionary (page does not exist)">Halpern's KLD indexing system</a>, with kyo-iku kanji color-coded by grade level.</div></div></div>
<p>Japanese school children are expected to learn 1,006 basic kanji characters, the <i><a href="/wiki/Ky%C5%8Diku_kanji" title="Kyōiku kanji">kyōiku kanji</a></i>, before finishing the sixth grade. The order in which these characters are learned is fixed. The <i>kyōiku kanji</i> list is a subset of a larger list, originally of 1,945 kanji characters, in 2010 extended to 2,136, known as the <i><a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Dy%C5%8D_kanji" title="Jōyō kanji">jōyō kanji</a></i> – characters required for the level of fluency necessary to read newspapers and literature in Japanese. This larger list of characters is to be mastered by the end of the ninth grade.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Schoolchildren learn the characters by repetition and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radical_(Chinese_character)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radical (Chinese character) (page does not exist)">radical</a>.
</p><p>Students studying Japanese as a foreign language are often required by a curriculum to acquire kanji without having first learned the vocabulary associated with them. Strategies for these learners vary from copying-based methods to <a href="/wiki/Mnemonic" title="Mnemonic">mnemonic</a>-based methods such as those used in <a href="/wiki/James_Heisig" title="James Heisig">James Heisig</a>'s series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Remembering_the_Kanji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Remembering the Kanji (page does not exist)">Remembering the Kanji</a></i>. Other textbooks use methods based on the <a href="/wiki/Etymology" title="Etymology">etymology</a> of the characters, such as Mathias and Habein's <i>The Complete Guide to Everyday Kanji</i> and Henshall's <i>A Guide to Remembering Japanese Characters</i>. Pictorial mnemonics, as in the text <i>Kanji Pict-o-graphix</i>, are also seen.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_government" title="Japanese government" class="mw-redirect">Japanese government</a> provides the <i><a href="/wiki/Kanji_kentei" title="Kanji kentei">Kanji kentei</a></i> (日本漢字能力検定試験 <i>Nihon kanji nōryoku kentei shiken</i>; "Test of Japanese Kanji Aptitude") which tests the ability to read and write kanji. The highest level of the <i>Kanji kentei</i> tests about 6,000 kanji.
</p>

</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> DeFrancis, John (1990). <i>The Chinese Language: Fact and Fantasy</i>. Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0824810686" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8248-1068-6</a>.
</li>
<li> Hadamitzky, W., and Spahn, M., (1981) <i>Kanji and Kana</i>, Boston: Tuttle.
</li>
<li> Hannas, William. C. (1997). <i>Asia's Orthographic Dilemma</i>. Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/082481892X" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8248-1892-X</a> (paperback); <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0824818423" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8248-1842-3</a> (hardcover).
</li>
<li> Kaiser, Stephen (1991). Introduction to the Japanese Writing System. In <i>Kodansha's Compact Kanji Guide</i>. Tokyo: Kondansha International. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/4770015534" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 4-7700-1553-4</a>.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marc_Hideo_Miyake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marc Hideo Miyake (page does not exist)">Miyake, Marc Hideo</a> (2003). <i>Old Japanese: A Phonetic Reconstruction</i>. New York, London: RoutledgeCurzon.
</li>
<li> Morohashi, Tetsuji. 大漢和辞典 <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dai_Kan-Wa_Jiten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dai Kan-Wa Jiten (page does not exist)">Dai Kan-Wa Jiten</a></i> (Comprehensive Chinese–Japanese Dictionary) 1984–1986. Tokyo: Taishukan
</li>
<li> Mitamura, Joyce Yumi and Mitamura, Yasuko Kosaka (1997). <i>Let's Learn Kanji</i>. Tokyo: Kondansha International. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/4770020686" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 4-7700-2068-6</a>.
</li>
<li> Unger, J. Marshall (1996). <i>Literacy and Script Reform in Occupation Japan: Reading Between the Lines</i>. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0195101669" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-19-510166-9</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a> 
</p>
<ul>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.infomongolia.com/lesson-category/67">Learning Kanji</a>, an animated application for the 1st Grade Kanji.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nihongomaster.com/dictionary/kanji">Kanji Dictionary</a> online Free Kanji Dictionary 
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~jwb/cgi-bin/wwwjdic.cgi?1C">Jim Breen's WWWJDIC server</a> used to find Kanji from English or romanized Japanese
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.romajidesu.com/kanji/">RomajiDesu Kanji Dictionary</a> a comprehensive Kanji dictionary with strokes order and various lookup methods.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.1776kanji.com/kanji/explore.php?kanji=&amp;doku=off">Kanji Explorer</a> More than 13000 Kanji
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.languagebug.com/kanji_q">KanjiQ</a> – Kanji flashcard tool that runs on mobile phones.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jishop.com">JISHOP</a> – Japanese-English computer kanji dictionary
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www2.gol.com/users/jpc/Japan/Kanji/KanjiLearn/">KanjiLearn</a> – Electronic set of 2135 two-sided kanji flashcards, as easy to use as paper flashcards.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nihongo.j-talk.com/kanji/">Convert Kanji to Romaji, Hiragana</a>—Converts Kanji and websites to forms that are easy to read and gives a word by word translation
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://tangorin.com/multiradical/">Tangorin</a>—Find kanji fast by selecting their elements
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://homepage2.nifty.com/TAB01645/">Dictionary of Kokuji</a> in Japanese
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://learnjapanese.elanguageschool.net/kanji-jlpt-lists">Learn Japanese Kanji</a>—How to write Kanji in Japanese
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.japanese-kanji.com/">Drill the kanji</a>—online Java tool (Asahi-net)
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://kanjialive.com/">Kanji Alive</a>—Online kanji learning tool in wide use at many universities, colleges and high-schools.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.realkanji.com/">Real Kanji</a>—Practice kanji using different typefaces.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.japanesestudies.org.uk/articles/2005/Tomoda.html">Change in Script Usage in Japanese: A Longitudinal Study of Japanese Government White Papers on Labor</a>, discussion paper by Takako Tomoda in the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.japanesestudies.org.uk/"><i>Electronic Journal of Contemporary Japanese Studies</i></a>, August 19, 2005.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.taipansoftware.com/en/japanese/dictionary/">Kanji Dictionary</a>, a kanji dictionary with a focus on compound-exploring.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.genetickanji.com/">Genetic Kanji</a>, Etymologically organized lists for learning kanji.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.kanjinetworks.com/">Kanji Networks</a>, a kanji etymology dictionary
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.saiga-jp.com/kanji_dictionary.html">Japanese Kanji Dictionary</a>—Each character is presented by a grade, stroke count, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~jwb/wwwjdicinf.html#sod_tag">stroke order</a>, phonetic reading and native Japanese reading. You can also listen to the pronunciation.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/jwb/wwwjdic?1KG">WWWJDIC Text Translator</a>—Takes Japanese text and returns each word with pronunciation (hiragana) and a translation in English.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.javadikt.net/en">JavaDiKt</a> — Open source kanji dictionary for desktop
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cymraeg.ru/daoulagad.html">Daoulagad Han</a> — Mobile OCR kanji dictionary, OCR interface to the UniHan database
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jisho.org/">Denshi Jisho</a> — Online Japanese dictionary
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Glyph_conversion">Glyph conversion</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.geocities.jp/qjitai/">A simple Shinjitai – Kyūjitai converter</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://yurara.kir.jp/material/kanji.html">A practical Shinjitai – Kyūjitai – Simplified Chinese character converter</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://homepage3.nifty.com/jgrammar/ja/tools/tradkan0.htm">A complex Shinjitai – Kyūjitai converter</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.skycn.com/soft/44716.html">A downloadable Shinjitai – Kyūjitai – Simplified Chinese character converter</a> – <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sjwx.net/zht.rar">Download directly</a>
</li>
</ul>

<div id="p-search" role="search">
	<h3><label for="searchInput">Search</label></h3>
